results.title: Len Lye compilation
results.brief_description:
Includes the following five titles which typify Lye’s technique of directly scratching on the leader and other various techniques directly onto the film.

Tusalava (1929). Lye’s first film was originally accompanied by live music by Jack Ellit. No score was ever found, so the film presented here is silent, a vision of the beginnings of life on earth - mixing Maori, silent and modernist influences.

Rhythm (1957). Live images of a car assembly line lead into Lye’s traditional white scratches, synchronised to African drum music.

Free radicals (1979). Set against African drum music, images are provided by scratches on black leader, created using a variety of tools. Supported by a grant from the New Zealand Film Commission.

Particles in space (1979). New kinds of scratch imagery reflect the disparate element of the title as dots and dashes squiggle about the screen. Supported by a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. A Federal agency, Washington, D.C

Tal farlow (1980). Jazz guitarist Tal Farlow provides the background music to Lye’s final film, which, although begun in the 50’s, was not recommenced until the 1980’s, only he died before completing it. It contains geometrical scratches and was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones, under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.

production_dates.notes: The films come from the years 1929, 1957, 1979 and 1980.

results.title: Tal Farlow
results.brief_description: Jazz guitarist Tal Farlow provides the background music to Lye’s final film, which, although begun in the 1950s, was not recommenced until the 1980s. Unfortunately he died before completing it. It contains vertical white scratches as well as geometric white scratches on black. It was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.

It was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.

results.title: Free radicals
results.brief_description:
A primitive kinetic dance of white lines and angles meticulously scratched onto black and white film over an 8 month period and then edited and retrospectively matched with an African field tape of the Bagirmi tribe. The title is a reference to modern physics, ‘free radicals’ being particles of energy. The original version was a major award winner at the Experimental Film Competition at the 1958 Brussels World Fair. This revised version was a reworking of the
original by Lye in 1979, with financial assistance from
the New Zealand Film Commission. He deleted approximately 1 min. from his first version, made in 1958.

results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for Aboriginal Australians to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work whereas traditional Aborigines did not recognise the western idea of work and preferred to follow their own cultural identity. Then came the mission stations, removal of Aboriginal children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when black Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: Archival prints compilation: Department of Agriculture collection
results.brief_description:
1. Farm Newsreel ‘A Crop of Records’ - Deals with different types of Victorian wheat and the ‘bumper’ wheat crop that has been produced. Nice colours and shots of iconic wheat farming imagery featuring tractors and farmers at work. Nice contrast between yellow wheat, blue sky and red machinery. Interviews a farmer about his wheat crop and then promotes overseas wheat export and shows ports at Brisbane and Geelong. Good ‘The End’ 6 minutes.

  2. The Argentine Ant - Made by the CSIRO film unit, details the dangers of the Argentine Ant and how to prevent its spread. Opens with well-illustrated stills of the globe and a map of Australia, before focusing on what makes the Argentine Ant such a pest. Good shot of ants crawling over a hand (2 mins). Details how to spray insecticide properly in order to contain and kill the ants. Good footage of a ‘spray gang’ at work in a community. Cute aerial illustration showing where to correctly spray. Nice shot near end of film at an airport runway featuring a plane landing while two men spray nearby. 10 minutes.

  3. Target - Five Crown - Good title illustration. ‘Five Crown’ relates to high-quality sultana produce. Film goes to show the many techniques needed to correctly produce sultanas at a high standard. Very good colour/shots throughout featuring grapes in different stages before being dried and turned into sultanas. Good ‘The End. 10 minutes.

  4. Dressing a Chicken - Good Titles. Details how to properly dress a chicken carcase. Opens with a comical example of how not to dress a chicken properly, before cutting to someone using the proper techniques. Shot in a sparse studio with a light blue background using minimal shots. Basic show and tell with a demonstrator and narrator. Gruesome to watch, but funny in parts. Good ‘The End’. 7 minutes.
